solution.text:
It is given that \(\bigtriangleup \) PRQ ~ \(\bigtriangleup \) TSU
\(\Rightarrow \angle TSU=\angle PRQ \Rightarrow \angle VSU=\angle WRQ\)
Also, \( \frac {TS}{PS}=\frac {US}{QR}\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac {2\times VS}{2\times WR}=\frac {US}{QR}\)
So now in \(\bigtriangleup \) UVS and\(\bigtriangleup \) QWR
we have \(\frac {VS}{WR}=\frac {US}{QR}\) and \(\angle VSU=\angle WRQ\)
\(\Rightarrow \bigtriangleup \) UVS ~ \(\bigtriangleup \) QWR
Similarly we can prove and say, \(\bigtriangleup \) UVT ~ \(\bigtriangleup \) QWT

content.text:
In the given figure \(\bigtriangleup \) PRQ ~ \(\bigtriangleup \) TSU
QW and UV are the medians of the \(\bigtriangleup \) PRQ and \(\bigtriangleup \) TSU repectively.
Choose the correct statements from the options given below
